<speak>
Defense to the Critics <break time="500ms"/>
Response to the Books About Synods
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
521-522 SANCTI HILARII
APOLOGETICA AD REPREHENSORES
LIBRI DE SYNODIS RESPONSA

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Section 1 In this section, although it caused some scandal, the Easterners resisted the Anomoeans. If this statement had been carefully considered, perhaps my entire argument would not have seemed suspicious. For I did not remain silent about what would be heard as scandalous.

Section 2 At the beginning of section thirteen, after the reading of the first decree of the Council of Ancyra, all the explanations given by the Council of Ancyra, described in this book, if they have any faults, those faults belong to them; otherwise, they are not considered to have faults in public opinion. However, I knew they had only been reported to Sirmium.

Section 3 Section seventy-seven refers to the explanation of the term homoousion, meaning "of the same substance," with a faithful and pious understanding. I don't think anyone needs reminding why I emphasized "piety" in relation to "similar substance." It’s because I understood both the impiety and the importance of saying not only "equal" but also "the same," so that the similarity you, Brother Lucifer, wanted to be preached would not be disapproved. Nonetheless, I remind you that only the pious understanding of similarity, which proclaims the unity of substance, should be preached.

Section 4 In manuscripts, this section continues seamlessly from the previous one and pertains to section seventy-eight: Oh zealous men of apostolic and evangelical doctrine, how much hope have you brought for the revival of true faith? But while praising them, I was misunderstood and criticized by some. I did not say they brought the true faith, but the hope of reviving it, so that just as they were heard, we too might be heard against Valens and Ursacius, and our respectful address would avoid any insolent abuse. As I continue, especially in section ninety-one, I reveal the hidden scandals of their expositions even more bitterly and reproachfully.

Section 5 But I pray, most holy men, that you consider my concerns with good grace.
chunks.original_latin:
I. In haec num. 3: Et licet non sine aliquo aurium
scandalo . . . . restiterint Orientales Anomoeis. Si diligenter sententia haec expensa esset, forte
totius tractatus mei ratio non fuisset suspiciosa. Non
enim  tacui esse illic, quod non nisi cum scandalo
esset audiendum. II. Initio num. 13, post recitationem primi decreti Ancyranae synodi. Expositiones omnes (Ancyranae synodi, quae hoc
libro describuntur), si quid habent criminis, intra se
habent; caeterum non habere in publica facie existimantur. Sed quia scirem ea sola Sirmium esse delata
(f eas solas delatas). III. Respicit ista num. 77: Exposita similis substantiae,
quae homoeusion appellatur, fideli ac pia
 intelligentia. Non puto quemquam admonendum, in hoc loco ut
expendat, quare dixerim SIMILIS SUBSTANTIAE
 PIAM INTELLIGENTIAM, nisi quia intelligerem et
impiam: et idcirco similem, non solum aequalem,
sed etiam eamdem dixisse, ut neque similitudinem,
quam tu, frater Lucifer, praedicari volueras, improbarem;
et tamen solam piam esse similitudinis intelligentiam
admonerem, quae unitatem substantiae
praedicaret. IV. In mss. cum superiori uno tenore continuatum pertinet
ad hoc num. 78: O studiosi tandem apostolicae
atque evangelicae doctrinae viri . . . . quantam spem
revocandae verae fidei attulistis? In eo vero, quod laudans eos in invidiam deducor
a quibusdam; parum intellectus sum. Non enim eos
veram fidem, sed SPEM REVOCANDAE VERAE FIDEI
attulisse dixi: ut sicut illi auditi sunt, ita et nos
 ex hoc contra Valentem et Ursacium possemus audiri,
et  coaptandus ad eos allocutionis sermo
blandus nihil aliud, quam procacium conviciorum
effugeret foeditatem; cum amarius atque etiam probrosius
 in consequentibus (praesertim num 91), occulta
expositionum essem scandala proditurus. V. Aptatur his num. 80: Oro autem vos, sanctissimi
viri, ut cum bona venia sollicitudines meas aestimetis.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Consider wisely what it means to ask the holiest of men to listen kindly to the speaker, and whether flattering and rebuking are the same. This is mentioned because the envoys sent to Sirmium left some things unspoken, which I will reveal in sections ninety and ninety-one. However, I did not want to seem like I was making false accusations in matters that could be defended as excusable.

Section six. Regarding these matters in section eighty-seven: And although unwilling, I will respond, etc. It should be clear enough, Lord brother Lucifer, that I was reluctant to mention homoiousios. But since you were proclaiming the likeness of the Son to the Father, I had to explain it without fault.

Section Seven. This is followed by section eighty-eight: You think we should subscribe to the Synod of Samosata. Let us also subscribe to the Synod of Nicaea. Didn't I, when discussing homoiousios, show that it should only be received by referring to the unity of substance?

Section Eight. In the eyes of the critics, this is explained in section eighty-nine: It troubles me (with scandal) the bareness of homoiousios, etc. Could anyone think that I wanted to accept homoousion, about which I discussed these matters?

Section Nine. Similar to this, after bringing examples of things that deceive with external similarity, did I neglect the similarity?

Section Ten. This corresponds to section ninety: For sparing them, I still say nothing about the decrees made at Ancyra with scandal. Am I thought to remove suspicion from these matters or to praise those I spare? To spare and to spare with delay is neither improper nor lenient.

Section Eleven. In the manuscripts, the tenth continues into section ninety-one: To prove that homoousion is not to be condemned; likewise in this same section: It is impious what you dare, etc. Do I here allow a similar substance to be anything but one? If it is not to be confessed as one before, then later it will be impiously preached as similar.

Section Twelve. After this is section ninety-one: I do not know nor understand homoiousios, except only from the confession of similar essence, etc. Do I seem to have been able to prove what I did not know (by accepting homoiousios for non-substantial similarity)? Certainly not.
chunks.original_latin:
Pro prudentia vestra expendite, quid sit a sanctissimis
viris poscere, ut cum bona venia audiant dicentem;
et an ejusdem sit adulari, et objurgare. Hoc ideo ita dictum est,  quia quae ad praesens tacita
ab his (Legatis Sirmium missis) fuissent, eram
proditurus (num 90 et 91); non tamen in his, quae
possent tamquam excusabilia defendi, viderer calumniari. VI. Attinet ad haec num. 87: Et ego invitus licet,
respondebo, etc. Satis absolute, Domine frater Lucifer, cognosci
potuit, invitum me homoeusii mentionem habere. Sed
quia tu similitudinem Filii ad Patrem praedicabas,
demonstratio ejus a me fuit exponenda sine vitio. VII. His subnectitur num. 88:  Synodo Samosatenae
subscribendum putas.. Subscribamus et Nicaeae
synodo. Numquid et hic  de homoeusione legentem, admonui,
non aliter ostendens suscipi oportere, nisi ad
unitatem substantiae referretur? VIII. Reprehensorum oculis exponit hoc num. 89: Et
me movet (cum scandalo) homoeusii nuditas, etc. Anne quisquam me existimare poterit homoeusion
velle suscipere, de quo ista tractavi? IX. Huic affine, adducitur post allata exempla eorum
quae externa similitudine fallunt. Numquid et hic similitudinis negligens fui? 523-524 X. Convenit his num. 90: Parcens enim
adhuc de his nihil dico, quae Ancyrae cum scandalo
decreta sunt. Anne existimor suspicionem ab his adimere, vel
ea laudare quibus parco? Parcere enim, et cum dilatione
ad hoc parcere, nihil improbi est et remissi. XI. In mss. decimo continuatum cadit in illa n. 91: Ut
probari possit homoeusion, non improbemus homousion;
item et in ista ejusdem numeri: Impium
est quod audetis, etc. An hic similem substantiam aliud patior esse nisi
unam? quae si non una sit antea confitenda, jam
 postea impie sit similis praedicanda. XII. Subjicitur post haec num. 91: Homoeusion nescio
nec intelligo, nisi tantum ab similis essentiae confessione,
etc. Numquid videor quod nescivi probare potuisse
(accipiendo homoeusion pro similitudine non substantiali)? Non utique.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
  The Catholic faith emphasizes unity and similarity. It mentions similarity to exclude division, not to break unity. So, even though I wasn't familiar with the terms <phoneme alphabet="ipa" ph="hoʊmoʊˈuːsioʊs">homoousios</phoneme> and <phoneme alphabet="ipa" ph="hoʊmoʊˈiːuːsioʊs">homoiousios</phoneme>, I still accepted similarity through unity. <break time="500ms"/> The next sentence immediately clarifies this.
<break time="2s"/>
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
Sed quia fides catholica non debeat
nisi per unitatem similitudinem credere; ut similitudinem
tantum ad excludendam unionem commemoret,
non ad discidium unitatis: idcirco me
dixi, cum nomina homousii atque homoeusii nescissem,
tamen per unitatem similitudinem recepisse. Hoc ipsum statim sequens sententia absolvit.
